author: .vbuterin
content: In the 3-layer scheme (C1, C2 and S as in my ethresearch post) the crazy merges would happen once a day

author: .vbuterin
content: computing a witness for a block would take time O(C1)

author: .vbuterin
content: computing a witness for the state would take time O(S)

author: .vbuterin
content: So if we have `size(C1) / size(block) = size(S) / size(C1)`

author: .vbuterin
content: And the refresh period is of length `size(C1) / size(block)` blocks

author: .vbuterin
content: then if it's possible to compute a witness for a block within the time of one block, then it's impossible to compute the witness for the state in `size(S) / size(C1)` blocks, which is equal to the duration of the refresh period

author: .vbuterin
content: That said, `size(C1) / size(block)` could be a lot of overhead, which is why you could have more layers of caching, so eg. `size(C[i+1]) / size(C[i]) = size(C[1]) / size(block) = 4`

author: .vbuterin
content: And then the refresh period for `C[i]` would be `4 ** (i+1)` blocks
